item.title: Everything You Need To Know About Dragon Quest 3 HD-2D Remake
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/dragon-quest-3-hd-2d-remake-differences-explained-1851691902

It’s been nearly four decades since Dragon Quest III first landed and it rapidly became one of the most adored RPGs out there. Whether you’ve played the highly-praised original or want to dive into the game for the first time, you’re in luck! Dragon Quest III HD-2D Remake brings the experience to modern hardware with a slew of changes and improvements.

This top-tier RPG, which serves as a prequel to Dragon Quest and Dragon Quest II, launches on November 14, so you don’t have to wait much longer to check it out. But if you’re on the fence, or just want to know more about what’s headed your way in the remake, here’s what you need to know.

Dragon Quest III HD-2D Remake isn’t the first Dragon Quest game to get remade, but it is the first to be reimagined in the HD-2D format, which has become a popular visual style since 2018's Octopath Traveler broke onto the scene. This charming aesthetic allows the game to maintain its retro vibe while looking modern at the same time, which should help it appeal to nostalgic fans and newcomers equally.

But its snazzy new graphical style certainly isn’t the only fresh addition to this full-blown remake of the RPG classic. Dragon Quest III HD-2D Remake also comes sporting numerous quality-of-life changes to ensure that the adventure is accessible to old and new fans alike.

Here’s the coolest new stuff you can expect from the game:

  • You can save anywhere! Woohoo!
  • You can increase the speed of battles and dialogue! Very cool!
  • You can choose between three difficulty modes! Rad!
  • You can pick a new vocation called the Monster Wrangler! Nice!
  • You can finally use Chimera Wings to fast travel even when you’re inside. Hell yeah!
  • You can navigate the world easier with new objective markers. Right on!

These changes, along with other minor upgrades along the way, make this the definitive way to play Dragon Quest III.

Dragon Quest III HD-2D Remake is available on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X, Nintendo Switch, and PC.

And yes, you read that right: Dragon Quest III HD-2D Remake is not available for older consoles like PS4 and Xbox One. So if you’re still rocking one of those older machines, you’ll need to wait until you upgrade to current-generation hardware to play this one.

If you’re planning to play Dragon Quest III HD-2D Remake on your PC, rest assured that it’s not a particularly demanding game. The minimum specs to run it are pretty reasonable. Here are the minimum and recommended specs.

Minimum specs:

  • Windows 10
  • Intel Core i3-6100 / AMD Ryzen 3 1200
  • NVIDIA GeForce GTX 750 / AMD Radeon RX 460 / Intel Arc A380
  • 20 GB available storage space
  • 8 GB RAM
  • DirectX 12

Recommended specs:

  • Windows 10
  • Intel Core i3-6100 / AMD Ryzen 3 1200
  • NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 / AMD Radeon RX 470 / Intel Arc A580
  • 20 GB available storage space
  • 8 GB RAM
  • DirectX 12

Dragon Quest III HD-2D Remake costs $59.99 on every platform.

If you know for a fact you’d like to pick it up, you can earn a nifty bonus for pre-ordering it. All digital pre-orders will receive a trouble-free travel kit.

What is a trouble-free travel kit, you ask? Well, it’s a neat little collection of items that can help you get a headstart in the game. Here’s everything you get:

  • One pair of elevating shoes
  • Three seeds of life
  • Three seeds of strength
  • Three seeds of defense
  • Three seeds of agility
  • Three seeds of magic

The seeds can be used to increase a character’s stats by a small amount each, while the elevating shoes grant you EXP as you walk, which is pretty damn cool.

You know what else is cool? This HD-2D remake of a beloved game is only the first on the way. Keep an eye out for the combo-title Dragon Quest I & II HD-2D Remake in 2025 if you want to own the full Erdrick Trilogy.

item.title: Terrible Borderlands Movie Still Helped Sell More Games
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/borderlands-4-movie-sequel-sales-box-office-1851691830

The Borderlands movie arrived in 2024, after years in development, only to rake in $15 million at the domestic box office. It was an epic flop, only overshadowed later on went Joker: Folie à Deux went “hold my beer” and failed even more spectacularly. At least with Borderlands, there was a video game franchise attached to it that could still reap the rewards of a moment in the spotlight, and according to Take-Two, which now owns Borderlands, that’s exactly what happened.

Suggested Reading

What Is Dragonsplague? Dragon’s Dogma 2’s Devastating Contagion Explained

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

“Obviously that movie was disappointing,” CEO Strauss Zelnick told IGN on Wednesday. “That said, it actually sold more catalog. So, I don’t think it hurt at all, if anything I think it may have helped a little bit. It does highlight something that I’ve spoken about many times which is the difficulty of bringing our intellectual property to another medium.”

Despite a star-studded cast and a big marketing campaign, the movie garnered terrible reviews and bombed opening weekend. Production on the film adaptation began way back in 2011, and the final result ended up being loud, chaotic, and somehow still boring. “It is devoid of humanity and personality, despite trying very, very hard to establish that it is quirky,” Kotaku’s Alyssa Mercante wrote in her review. “It is the woman with frozen peas on her head in the grocery store aisle—she’s so crazzzzzyy, love her! It should not exist.”

While a critically-acclaimed blockbuster might have done a lot to help catapult the Borderlands franchise to new heights, it’s possible the movie was so bad that a surprising number of people wanted the good version of the sci-fi treasure hunting experience, and so opted to spend the price a theater ticket on the much better games themselves.

Zelnick has spoken in the past about why Take-Two, which also owns Red Dead Redemption and Grand Theft Auto, has been so cautious to try to turn those big names into film and TV spin-offs. “Make no mistake about it,” he told Inverse last year, “it is a very risky move, and I’m pretty risk averse with regard to our intellectual property.”

Less risky is a sequel that iterates on an existing formula that’s already proven to be a hit. Borderlands 4 is currently set to launch sometime in 2025. It was officially revealed earlier this year, with a short teaser that nevertheless gave fans a lot to speculate about.

.

item.title: Dance Upon The Graves Of Your Enemies With This Brutal Diablo 4 Rogue Build
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/diablo-4-vessel-of-hatred-rogue-build-guide-1851691792

Welcome to my Rogue “Dance of Knives” build guide, where I’ll show you the build that made me fall in love with the Rogue class in Diablo 4: Vessel of Hatred.

Suggested Reading

Diablo IV - Bear Bender Build

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

Beginner Leveling & Endgame Build - Rogue

Good news, Rogues! My favorite build in Diablo 4: Vessel of Hatred is great for both leveling and endgame content.

If you’ve read my Spiritborn guide, you’ll already know I love movement, and this is the most movement-focused build I’ve found for the Rogue. Like an amped up ‘Whirlwind’ Barbarian build, the ‘Dance Of Knives’ Rogue build is all about using its signature ability as often as possible. It doesn’t take much to get it going, and once you do, it’s fairly easy to use it all the time.

The basic idea is to use abilities like Concealment, Dark Shroud, Shadow Clone, and others to boost your damage, then hold Dance of Knives until you run out of charges. Then use Blade Shift and other abilities, get your charges back, then begin again.

Read More: Destroy Everything In Sight With This Beginner Diablo 4 Barbarian Build

When picking up gear or modifying traits, ‘Movement speed’ is king. Enhanced Dance Of Knives will let you use the ability endlessly once you can move 30 meters during one use of it as it will continually refresh itself. Then, once you can hold Dance Of Knives and never run out of charges, you can start focusing on boosting Crit Chance, increasing Vulnerability, and other things to boost your damage even further.

With this build you’ll level quickly, easily, and spin right into the endgame, where you can keep the gravy train going as this build is more than lethal enough to keep you going for a long time.

Basic Skills

  • Blade Shift 1/5 - Fundamental Blade Shift

Core Skills

  • Stutter Step 3/3
  • Target Practice 3/3

Agility Skills

  • Dance Of Knives 5/5 - Disciplined Dance Of Knives
  • Unstable Elixirs 3/3
  • Trick Attacks 3/3
  • Weapon Mastery 3/3

Subterfuge Skills

  • Concealment 1/5 - Subverting Concealment
  • Exploit 3/3
  • Malice 3/3
  • Dark Shroud 1/5 - Countering Dark Shroud

Imbuement Skills

  • Shadow Imbuement 1/5 - Blended Shadow Imbuement

Ultimate Skills

  • Shadow Clone 5/5 - Supreme Shadow Clone
  • Second Wind 1/3
  • Haste 3/3
  • Aftermath
  • Unto Dawn
  • Impetus

Key Passive

  • Momentum

Now that you have every tool securely in your arsenal, make the forces of Hatred regret ever crossing you. Carry out your revenge (and take what you can) as you slink your way through Sanctuary, Wanderer.

.
